citations.narrative:
The facility is not following the Program of Vet Care (PVC) for vaccinations. The current Program of Vet Care prescribes
for the rabies vaccination to be performed at 18 weeks of age, then at 1 year, then every 3 years after booster at 1 year of
age. The distemper and parvovirus vaccinations are to be given every 4 weeks up to 18 weeks of age, then given yearly
after that.
Five adult dogs had no record of a current distemper, parvovirus, or rabies vaccination:
- Angel #7601
- Aubrey #7603
- Macy #9663
- Chloe #0418
- Jane #9668
Thirty-nine adult dogs are not up to date on the rabies vaccination (the distemper and parvovirus vaccines are current).
- Gemma #3058
- Dawn #0413
- Murphy #7777
- Paw Paw #4819
- Hunter #8904
- Snickers #2424
- Jet #9848
- (No Name) #9667
- Crown #2434
- Georgina #3069
- Gia #3067
- Addy #9726
- Tootsie #6346
- Lucy #6835
- Avery #0252
- Ollie #6839
- Zoey #0253
- Brooke #0254
- Sassy #0255
- Olive #0256
- Emma #4958
- Haley #8902
- Betsy #0403
- Isabelle #6416
- Valerie #2956
- Jolly #1846
- Rose #8895
- Wendy #8754
- Sandy #2421
- Eyla #4953
- Kelly #8917
- Sunshine #6359
- Daisy #0239
- Carmen #0231
- Quincey #0187
- Judy #7761
- Jessie #7760
- Pebble #4621
- Iris #7759
Failure to follow the PVC leaves the dogs susceptible to distemper, parvovirus, and rabies, which are viruses that, if
contracted, will cause pain and distress. It is also important for dogs to be vaccinated since rabies is a disease that can
infect humans. Vaccinations are also important in pregnant and nursing dogs because they will pass immunity from the
vaccines onto their offspring. Correct by administering all of the vaccines required by the Animal Welfare Act (distemper,
parvovirus, and rabies) in accordance with a schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian and vaccine manufacturer
recommendations. Correct by: July 31, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility is not following the Program of Vet Care (PVC) for vaccinations. The current Program of Vet Care prescribes 
for the rabies vaccination to be performed at 18 weeks of age, then at 1 year, then every 3 years after booster at 1 year of 
age. The distemper and parvovirus vaccinations are to be given every 4 weeks up to 18 weeks of age, then given yearly 
after that.  
 
Five adult dogs had no record of a current distemper, parvovirus, or rabies vaccination: 
- Angel #7601 
- Aubrey #7603 
- Macy #9663 
- Chloe #0418 
- Jane #9668 
 
Thirty-nine adult dogs are not up to date on the rabies vaccination (the distemper and parvovirus vaccines are current).  
- Gemma #3058 
- Dawn #0413 
- Murphy #7777 
- Paw Paw #4819 
- Hunter #8904

- (No Name) #9667

- Ollie #6839

- Zoey #0253

Failure to follow the PVC leaves the dogs susceptible to distemper, parvovirus, and rabies, which are viruses that, if 
contracted, will cause pain and distress. It is also important for dogs to be vaccinated since rabies is a disease that can 
infect humans. Vaccinations are also important in pregnant and nursing dogs because they will pass immunity from the 
vaccines onto their offspring. Correct by administering all of the vaccines required by the Animal Welfare Act (distemper, 
parvovirus, and rabies) in accordance with a schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian and vaccine manufacturer 
recommendations. Correct by: July 31, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
 n
